author: Michael McNulty
title: Governance Co-Laboratory
description: On-chain governance presents novel challenges and remains difficult to change. How might we make and learn from our mistakes together?

assessments.note: It is not clear how this proposal meets the objects of this fund to "help the Catalyst community to get better at distributed decision making within the next two Catalyst rounds".

As the related "Catalyst catapult" proposal, this is too vague for me to deduce what the goal is. 
If you want to curate onboarding materials, I suggest you just do it and then ask for money for continuing doing it.
The part about compensation frameworks really amounts to saying "give me the money and I'll figure out how to use it".

The theme of the proposal certainly is about improving distributed decision making but the how, where and by whom are very unclear. There are definitely some good thoughts presented in the proposal but a plan to turn them into actionable items is for the most part lacking.

Improving Catalyst is important and the whole community would benefit from it. On-chain governance is going to be hard but is gonna bring a lot of value. It is worth to allocate some of the funds to improving it.
The proposers have the experience the to deliver, however the plan lacks concrete deliverables thus successful implementation is hard to judge.

It's very hard to judge the experience of the proposer as no reference point is provided. As for the successful implementation of the project it's hard to judge what the project will actually attempt. There are hints at some actions like fostering collaboration and research, but not an actual plan or auditable metrics.

Given that the proposer is a engaged community member, retro organizer and facilitator it is likely that this is gonna be improved successfully / is gonna bring loads of knowlege on what to do better. They are already committed as they are gonna continue their work even if they are not getting funded. The budget is appropriate.

The proposal does not contain any milestones or success criteria. Some good questions are asked but no path is shown how the proposed project might answer them, other than curating unspecified onboarding materials and compensating people for unspecified contributions.

Judging by the comments, the proposal seems to be a recognised member of the Catalyst community, but other than that no info about him is provided, no link to previous works, no references. The proposal lacks a detailed budget or an implementation roadmap. The proposer did not complete the steps required by the self assessment checklist. No metrics or a description of what success would look like are provided.

There is no roadmap but it is not a proplem as the proposal is different to others meaning it is more experminental. The first goal is to work with other projects to identify the areas of greatest need.

solution: Low-stakes laboratory to experiment with novel organizational structures and processes, free from highly technical considerations.
